issue.title: Quote text-based arguments in display names for parameterized tests

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

While discussing #4714 with @sormuras, he inquired about the `'null'` display name, which sparked an idea...

Namely, it would be quite nice to have an auto-quote feature for argument values in the display name for a `@ParameterizedClass` or `@ParameterizedTest`.

I therefore propose that we introduce a `boolean quoteText() default true` attribute (or similar) in `@ParameterizedClass` and `@ParameterizedTest` which signals to the `ParameterizedInvocationNameFormatter` that it should wrap `CharSequence` values (naturally including `String`) in double quotes (`""`) and wrap Character` values in single quotes (`''`).

Defaulting to `true` would make this an opt-out feature, but we could of course default to `false` to make it an opt-in feature.

Though, since we are introducing this in 6.0, perhaps it's better to make it an opt-out feature.

Note, however, that a `null` `CharSequence`/`Character` value would continue to be displayed as `null`, not `"null"` or `'null'`.

## Related Issues

- #4714 
- #4783 
- #4786

issue.title: Replace ISO control characters in display names

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

body:
Sorry, this is a topic I would normally avoid and even more so because ...
> After discussing this within the team, we decided ...

... has taken place. But I don't think this is a good move, so I'd like to share my point-of-view before the release candidates surface:
```java
    @CsvSource(value = {"short,' ',23" , "long text,'',42" })
    @ParameterizedTest
    void multipleArgs(String text, String spacing, int number) {}
```
ConsoleLauncher result on version 5.13.4 ...
```
├─ JUnit Jupiter ✔
│  └─ DemoTest ✔
│     └─ multipleArgs(String, String, int) ✔
│        ├─ [1] text=short, spacing= , number=23 ✔
│        └─ [2] text=long text, spacing=, number=42 ✔
```
ConsoleLauncher result on version 6.0.0-M2 ...
```
├─ JUnit Jupiter ✔
│  └─ DemoTest ✔
│     └─ multipleArgs(String, String, int) ✔
│        ├─ [1] text = short, spacing =  , number = 23 ✔
│        └─ [2] text = long text, spacing = , number = 42 ✔
```
On readability ...
 - Whitespace character is often an important parameter value. Also it serves as format separator, for good reasons indeed - but these multiple duties are a readability concern imho. Therefore I am conservative about inserting even more whitespace to this context - and especially when there is already another separator character  `=` that has to be there anyway.

On scrolling sideways _or trying to fit two examples beside eachother on a Powerpoint slide_  ...
 - For someone who likes to have many parameters, the test-name length is a concern. I'm uncomfortable with having 6 extra spaces in the above test names.

I understand here is a background context that is related to other issues, e.g. #4783, on which I think it would be better if the example test-name unfolds as `[1] FRUIT=apple, RANK=1`.

Hi @kaipe,

Thanks for the feedback.

Please note that this change was simply the first action taken to address a larger theme in 6.0. See the following for details.

- #4716 
- #4714 

> ConsoleLauncher result on version 6.0.0-M2 ...
> 
> ```
> ├─ JUnit Jupiter ✔
> │  └─ DemoTest ✔
> │     └─ multipleArgs(String, String, int) ✔
> │        ├─ [1] text = short, spacing =  , number = 23 ✔
> │        └─ [2] text = long text, spacing = , number = 42 ✔
> ```

With 6.0 RC1 (or current snapshots), that will look like the following.

```
├─ JUnit Jupiter ✔
│  └─ DemoTest ✔
│     └─ multipleArgs(String, String, int) ✔
│        ├─ [1] text = "short", spacing = " ", number = "23" ✔
│        └─ [2] text = "long text", spacing = "", number = "42" ✔
```

If you don't want quoting and escaping, that can be disabled via the new `quoteTextArguments` attribute in `@ParameterizedTest`. See the [User Guide](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/user-guide/#writing-tests-parameterized-tests-display-names-quoted-text) for details.

We currently do not have any plans to revert these related changes. JUnit 6 is a major release and can therefore contain breaking changes, changes in display name formatting, etc. At the same time, we are fully aware of the fact that not everyone will be pleased by changes in display name formatting, and that's simply unavoidable.

In any case, we will take feedback into account and potentially reassess our options if there is considerable feedback from a large portion of the community.

Thank you for the heads up on quotation.

I believe it's a good thing, in part because it could make the `,` separation between parameters redundant. In the-spirit-of-short-test-names I'd be happy if the above test result would be displayed like this ...
```java
├─ JUnit Jupiter ✔
│  └─ DemoTest ✔
│     └─ multipleArgs(String, String, int) ✔
│        ├─ [1] text=short spacing=" " number=23 ✔
│        └─ [2] text="long text" spacing="" number=42 ✔
```

... where quotation is only applied where necessary.

I realize the above quotes-where-necessary layout is not in the cards for the 6.0.0 release. However, in the short run I think it'd better to replace the boolean `quoteTextArguments` attribute with an enum type attribute and therewith have the API compatible with future layouts on top of just true and false. Initial constants on enum could perhaps be `RELEASE_6_DEFAULT, RELEASE_5_ORIGINAL` and then the future is allowed to present additional constants to achieve `AS_IN_CSV_SOURCE` or `ONLY_AS_NEEDED_FOR_achieving_something` - but hopefully with somewhat better constant names :-)

In the long run I also believe it'd be good to support customized separation between parameters (e.g. `" "` instead of `", "`) and between name & value (e.g. `"="` instead of `" = "`).

Thanks for the additional feedback, @kaipe.

I had actually already considered only quoting "when necessary", and I had also considered introducing a `String` attribute to allow the user to define the parameter name-value separator with `" = "` as the default.

As for deciding if quoting is necessary, I suppose the logic would be to only quote if:

- something was escaped, or
- the text is empty, or
- the text contains whitespace (such as normal spaces)

Please note, however, that we only quote text-based source arguments. For example, if a source argument is an `Integer`, the value in the display name will not be quoted. The reason you're seeing `number = "23"` here is that the source is from a CSV record, which is always text-based.

In any case, _this_ issue is closed. So, if you'd like to discuss this further, feel free to start a discussion or open an issue.
